p.s: In order to present his critical view on the issue of language learning in the UK the author makes use of both stylistic devices and persuasive techniques, as well as a clear structure and numerous examples.
The article was published in The Telegraph, which is a popular paper.
Popular papers tend to mix facts with the own opinion of the author.
They use a more colloquial or informal language and tend to have not such a complex syntax.
If you take a look at the headline, you can see the three words can't, won't, don't which are directly repeated and enumerated in line 1.
These three words are giving the answer to the UK's national view on speakin foreign languages (ll. 1) in a negative way.
By the use of the pronoun our in ll. 1 the author wants to make everyone in the UK feel involved and part of the current issue.
To tighten up on the fact that they are all involved he says in ll. 5 that they have to re-commissioning our collective brains.

In view of the issue he emphasites the fact that for the past seven years, the number of UK students choosing to study foreign language at university level has been in steady decline (ll. 3) and even claims that more than 10.000 fewer language A-Level exams were taken last year than at the end of the 1990s, ... (ll. 9).
With this claim he wants to rely on his credibility and wants to underline how real the issue has become.
He mentions the progressive things, such as the languages in more primary schools, but also stresses out that there is a long haul ahead (l. 7) to fix this problem.
With his irony in (l. 12, l. 15) Perfectly intelligent people... Cobblers Worne exerts indirect criticism.
Because he thinks in contrast to the perfectly intelligent people that in a world of business not everyone can speak English.
He uses words like Cobblers (l. 15), and short forms like in l. 1, l. 13, l. 35... to involve every reader.
It is informal, but more common, which brings a big readership.
By saying things like more should (l. 26) or making use of adjectives with his opinion connected like sadly (l. 4) he emphasizes his point of view on the issue and gives at the end the solution.
By appealing to the parents of the UK and underlining the fact that he is also one, he wants to fix the issue.
They should be the essential strings to our children's bows (l. 34).
the text is arranged as an pyramid, so that the solutions stays in mind from the reader and that they (hopefully) spread awareness to the issue at home.
All in all one can say that the author tries to spread awareness to the problem and tries to convince the reader that the issue is real.

With short forms and colloquial language, as well as direct adressaddress he wants to create a community, so that everybody feels involved and everybody feels as a part of the problem and importantly as part of the solution.
